title: 111_s2661
content: The "Child Care Lending Pilot Act of 2009" establishes a loan program under the Small Business Administration for small business concerns in the child care industry. Key definitions are provided for terms like "Administration," "program," "small business concern," and "State." The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include restrictions and limitations on the authority of the Administration to provide loans. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include restrictions and limitations on the authority of the Administration to provide loans. In subsection (b)(1), changes are made to allow the proceeds of loans to be used by a development company to assist small, nonprofit child care businesses for approved business purposes. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 is amended to include restrictions and limitations on the authority of the Administration to provide loans to small, nonprofit child care businesses for approved business purposes. Eligibility requirements for these businesses include personal guarantees, clear collateral title, and meeting all criteria except for being a for-profit entity. The Small Business Investment Act of 1958 now includes restrictions on loans to small, nonprofit child care businesses. Eligibility requires personal guarantees, collateral, and meeting criteria except for being for-profit. Nonprofit child care businesses must have sufficient cash flow to meet loan obligations and operating expenses. Nonprofit child care businesses eligible for loans must meet specific criteria, including being organized under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, providing child care services for infants to pre-kindergarten children, and having a tangible net worth not exceeding $7,000,000. Nonprofit child care businesses eligible for loans must meet specific criteria, including being organized under section 501(c)(3) of the Internal Revenue Code, providing child care services for infants to pre-kindergarten children, having an average net income not exceeding $2,500,000 for the 2 completed fiscal years before the application, and being licensed as a child care provider by the State where the establishment is located. The amendment to U.S.C. 696(b)(1) removes subparagraph (B) and revises the language regarding the use of proceeds. Section 502(b)(1)(B) of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958 applies to loans authorized during a specific period. The Small Business Administration must submit reports on the implementation of the program every 6 months to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business. The reports should include the program implementation date, rules issuance date under section 5, and the number and amount of loans applied for and approved under section 502 of the Small Business Investment Act of 1958. The Small Business Administration must submit reports every 6 months to the Senate and House Committees on Small Business regarding loans disbursed to nonprofit and for-profit child care businesses under the program. The Comptroller General of the United States is required to submit a report on the program's first 2 years by March 31, 2012. The Small Business Administration must provide reports every 6 months to Congress on loans given to nonprofit and for-profit child care businesses. The Comptroller General must submit a report on the program's first 2 years by March 31, 2012, including evaluations on program implementation, participation of development companies, lenders, and small businesses, marketing strategies, and the number of small child care businesses applying for loans. The Small Business Administration is required to provide biannual reports to Congress on loans given to for-profit and nonprofit child care businesses. The Comptroller General must also submit a report by March 31, 2012, evaluating the program's first 2 years, including program implementation, participation of development companies, lenders, marketing strategies, and the number of small child care businesses applying for loans. The Small Business Administration must report to Congress biannually on loans to for-profit and nonprofit child care businesses. The report should include details on the total amount loaned, number of loans, average loan amount and term, loan performance metrics, and the percentage of children receiving subsidized assistance. The Small Business Administration collects necessary information from development companies and small child care businesses to carry out loan programs for child care businesses. Businesses must comply with requests for information from the Administration. The Administration must provide information collected to the Comptroller General of the United States for reporting purposes. The Administrator must issue final rules within 120 days to implement the loan program authorized under the Small Business Investment Act of 1958.
